keyText:
well.

in a skillful or effective way.

She speaks Japanese well.

teacher.

someone whose job is to teach.

a French/math/piano teacher

wall.

an upright side of a room inside a building.

On the opposite wall hung a valuable old painting.

safe.

protected from being hurt, damaged, lost, stolen, etc..

Will my car be safe if I park it on the street?

answer.

to give a spoken reply to a question.

I want you to answer one simple question.

each.

used for referring to all the people or things in a group, especially when considering every one separately.

Each request will be given careful consideration.

fish.

an animal that lives in water and swims. It breathes by using its gills and moves by using its tail and fins. Saltwater fish live in the ocean and freshwater fish live in rivers and lakes.

Little silver fish swam past.

thing.

an object, or an item. This word is used when you cannot or do not want to refer to the object or item in a more specific way.

What’s that thing over there on the table?

dress.

to put on clothes. This verb is common in writing, but when you are speaking it is more usual to say that you get dressed.

It only took her ten minutes to shower and dress.

look.

to direct your eyes toward someone or something so that you can see them.

Looking closely you could see traces of gray in her hair.

again.

used for saying that something happens or someone does something one more time when it has already happened or been done before.

You’ll have to tell me again – I wasn’t listening.

woman.

an adult female person.

We need more women in government.

bus.

a large road vehicle with a lot of seats which you pay to travel on, especially one that takes you fairly short distances and stops frequently.

by bus: The children go to school by bus.

nationality.

the legal status of being a citizen of a particular country.

British/American/German nationality

pay.

to give money in order to buy something.

pay for: Let me pay for dinner.

quarter.

one of four equal parts of something.

quarter of: Over a quarter of our income goes for food.

ask.

to speak or write to someone in order to get information from them.

I wondered who had given her the ring but was afraid to ask.

tall.

a tall person or object has greater height than the average person or object.

a tall thin woman

tree.

a very tall plant that has deep roots, a thick stem made of wood, and many branches.

As a child, Jed loved to climb trees.

say.

to express something using words.

“Nice to meet you,” he said with a smile.

sheep.

.

home.

the place where you live.

We go to a school close to our home.

near.

close to someone or something.

A group of students were standing near the entrance.

cat.

.

until.

happening or done up to a particular point in time, and then stopping.

Baker is expected to be here until the end of the week.

only.

used for emphasizing that an amount, number, size, age, percentage, etc. is small or smaller than expected.

The police station was only 150 metres away.

course.

a series of classes or lectures in an academic subject or a practical skill.

a drama/secretarial/Spanish course

choose.

to decide which you want from a number of people or things.

Do you feel that you chose the wrong career?

help.

to give someone support or information so that they can do something more easily.

If you are finding that difficult, I could help you.

boat.

a small vehicle that people use for traveling on water. Boats are usually smaller than ships, and are moved by means of sails, oars, or motors.

by boat: The only way to get there was by boat.

every.

used for referring to all the people or things of a particular type or in a particular group, or all the parts of something.

Every bedroom has its own private bathroom.

cow.

.

plant.

a living thing that grows in soil, has leaves and roots, and needs water and light from the sun to live.

a garden/pot/house plant

little.

used for referring to an extremely small amount of something.

There is little time to prepare for the exams.

school.

a place where children go to be taught.

It’s the biggest school in the city.

happy.

feeling pleased and satisfied.

The children seem very happy at school.

part.

one of the pieces, sections, aspects, etc. that something consists of.

It was a pretty boring class, but the part about using spreadsheets was quite useful.

written.

something that is written involves writing and not speaking or drawing.

written records

noise.

a loud or unpleasant sound.

The noise from the machines is deafening.

job.

work that you do regularly to earn money. When you ask someone about their job, you usually say “What do you do?”, and not “What is your job?” The answer would usually be “I am a ...” or “I work as a...”, and not “My job is...”.

job as: She has a job as a restaurant manager.

small.

not large in size, amount, or number.

These shoes are too small for me.

board.

a long thin flat piece of wood, used especially for making floors and other parts of buildings.

There’s a loose board in the bedroom floor.

study.

the process of learning about a subject by going to class and reading.

Libraries are not used only for study.

dark.

lacking light.

a dark and stormy night

question.

something that someone asks you when they want information.

answer a question: Why won’t you answer my question?

left.

on the side of your body that is to the west if you are facing north.

He wore a wedding ring on his left hand.

sleep.

to go into a natural state in which you are unconscious for a time and your body rests, especially for several hours at night.

The baby usually sleeps in the afternoon.

cross.

to go from one side of something such as a road or river to the other.

She wanted to be sure the children had crossed the road safely.

driver.

someone who drives a vehicle, especially as their job.

a taxi driver

tell.

to give information to someone.

If you see anything suspicious, tell the police.

place.

an area, or a position.

I don’t like crowded places.

week.

a period of seven days, usually counted from a Sunday.

He travels south two days a week.

pet.

.

quick.

able to move fast or do something fast.

He’s surprisingly quick for such a big man.

invite.

to ask someone to come to see you or to spend time with you socially.

How many people did you invite?

afternoon.

the period of time between the middle of the day and the beginning of the evening.

I’ve got a job interview on Tuesday afternoon.

word.

a single unit of written or spoken language.

The Latin word for a table is “mensa.”

but.

used for joining two ideas or statements when the second one is different from the first one, or seems surprising after the first one.

We’re making a lot of progress, but we’ve still got a long way to go.

sun.

.

bath.

the process of washing yourself or someone else in a bathtub.

The children need a bath tonight.

who.

used for asking which person is involved in something, or what someone’s name is.

Who killed John F. Kennedy?

ride.

to sit on an animal, especially a horse, and control its movements as it moves along.

I learned to ride only last year.

cup.

a small round container for a drink, usually with a handle.

Henry took the coffee cups into the kitchen.

movie.

.

bed.

a piece of furniture that you sleep on, consisting of a soft comfortable part called a mattress and a base.

double/twin/single bed: The room had two single beds in it.

get.

to obtain, receive, or be given something.

Ross’s father got a new job.

tonight.

in the evening or during the night of today.

Call me tonight when you get there.

lesson.

a period of time in which someone is taught a skill.

a driving/dancing/swimming lesson

change.

to become different, or to make someone or something different.

Some things never change.

breakfast.

the first meal you have in the morning.

What did you have for breakfast this morning?

life.

the period of time from someone’s birth until their death.

She devoted her life to helping others.

dictionary.

a reference resource which provides information about words and their meanings, uses, and pronunciations. A dictionary may be published as a printed book, or as a digital product such as a website or app, and it may be monolingual, bilingual, or multilingual..

a dictionary of the English language

something.

used for referring to a thing, idea, fact, etc. when you do not know or say exactly what it is.

I could smell something burning.

pig.

an animal with no fur and a curly tail kept by farmers for its meat. A female pig is called a sow and a young pig is called a piglet. The meat from a pig is called pork..

You greedy pig! You’ve eaten up all the ice cream.

shop.

a place where you buy things or where you pay for a service.

We ate lunch at a little coffee shop.

vegetable.

a part of a plant used as food, for example a potato, bean, or cabbage.

We grow all our own vegetables and herbs.

hot.

very high in temperature.

Cook the fish on a hot grill for 5 minutes.

sentence.

a group of words, usually including a subject and a verb, that express a statement, question, or instruction. A written sentence begins with a capital letter and ends with a period, question mark, or exclamation point..

She received the maximum sentence of ten years.

make.

to create or produce something by working.

Jane made coffee while the guests were finishing their dessert.

into.

used for stating what place a road, path, entrance, etc. leads to.

Is there another way into the building?

feel.

to be in a particular state as a result of an emotion or a physical feeling.

I was feeling very happy when we began our trip.

beard.

hair that grows on a man’s chin and cheeks.

his thick white beard

fruit.

a type of food that grows on trees or plants. It tastes sweet and contains seeds or a pit. Apples and oranges are fruit. Ripe fruit is ready to eat.

Peaches are my favorite fruit.

exciting.

making you feel excited.

The launch of our digital satellite service is one of the most exciting things I’ve worked on.

shoe.

something that you wear on each foot, usually over socks.

pair of shoes: She bought several pairs of shoes.

kind.

a type of person or thing.

kind of: What kind of person is she?

tomorrow.

on the day after today.

Are you going back home tomorrow?

language.

the method of human communication using spoken or written words.

Linguistics is the study of language and how people use it.

museum.

a building where many valuable and important objects are kept so that people can go and see them.

a science/folk/history museum

interesting.

something that is interesting makes you want to know about it or take part in it.

She’s an interesting new writer.

there.

used for introducing a statement about someone that exists or something that happens.

there is/are: There isn’t much time left.

kitchen.

.

colour.

.

yes.

used for telling someone that what they have said or asked is true or correct.

“Is that your car?” “Yes, it is.”

closed.

if a door, window, lid, etc. is closed, it is covering an open area, passage, or hole.

closed curtains

good.

of a high quality or standard.

We saw a really good movie last night.

sit.

to be in a position in which the lower part of your body rests on a seat or on the ground, while the upper part of your body is upright.

sit on a chair/bench/stool: Matt sat on a park bench, eating his lunch.

stay.

to remain in a particular place.

Stay right here, please.

or.

used for connecting possibilities or choices. In a list, “or” is usually used only before the last possibility or choice.

Which color do you want – red, green, yellow, or blue?

very.

used for emphasizing that a quality exists or is true to a great degree.

It was a very good movie.

meeting.

an occasion when people gather to discuss things and make decisions, either in person or using phones, the internet, etc..

meeting on/about: They organized meetings on a number of important political issues.

homework.

work that a teacher gives a student to do outside of class.

Have the kids done their homework?

page.

a sheet of paper in a book, newspaper, or magazine.

I tore a page out of my diary and wrote my phone number on it.

worry.

to feel nervous and upset because you keep thinking about a problem that you have or could have in the future.

worry about: People worry more about their health than they used to.

university.

an educational institution where students study for degrees and where academic research is done.

He was at the University of Wisconsin  (=studied there).

sea.

the large area of salt water that covers most of the surface of the Earth.

Tim went swimming in the sea.

drunk.

unable to control your actions or behavior because you have drunk too much alcohol.

get drunk (on something): She had gotten drunk on vodka.

meal.

an occasion when you eat, especially breakfast, lunch, or dinner.

The medicine should always be taken with meals.

hour.

a period of time that consists of 60 minutes. 30 minutes is usually called half an hour, 15 minutes can be called a quarter of an hour, and 45 minutes can be called three-quarters of an hour.

every hour: She checked on the children every hour.

friend.

someone you know well and like, but who is not a member of your family.

She’s visiting friends in Illinois.

eat.

to put food into your mouth and swallow it.

We sat on the grass and ate our sandwiches.

hand.

the part of your body at the end of each arm that you use for picking up and holding things.

Mrs. Bennet put her hands over her ears to shut out the noise.

worrying.

causing you to feel worried.

The most worrying trend is the sharp decline in young readers.

smoke.

a gray, black, or white cloud produced by something that is burning.

The air was thick with cigarette smoke.

shirt.

a piece of clothing that covers the top part of the body. It usually has long sleeves and buttons down the front. A woman’s shirt is often called a blouse..

One of his shirt buttons was missing.

sing.

to make music using your voice.

Malcolm likes singing in the shower.

window.

a frame in a wall with glass in it that lets light and air into a room and lets you see what is outside.

She just stood there staring out of the window.

cook.

to prepare food and heat it so that it is ready to eat.

Cook the apple slowly until it is soft.

catch.

to stop and hold something that is moving through the air, especially an object that someone throws.

She tossed the bag of potato chips to Kate, who caught it with one hand.

listen.

to pay attention to a sound, or to try to hear a sound.

When he speaks, everybody listens.

learn.

to gain knowledge or experience of something, for example by being taught.

a bright girl who is already learning the alphabet

spoken.

spoken language is things that people say, not things that they write.

examples of spoken and written English

conversation.

a talk between two or more people, usually a private and informal one.

Later in the evening, the conversation turned to politics.

holiday.

a day that is a celebration of something special, on which you do not have to work or go to school.

May 1st is a holiday in many European countries.

day.

one of the periods of time that a week is divided into, equal to 24 hours.

We’re going away for five days.

remember.

to have an image in your mind of a person, a place, or something that happened or was said in the past.

I can still remember every word of our conversation.

with.

if one person or thing is with another or does something with them, they are together or they do it together.

Hannah lives with her parents.

rain.

water that falls in drops from clouds in the sky.

Drops of rain ran down the window pane.

mouth.

the part of your face below your nose that you use to eat and speak. The corners of your mouth are the two outside ends of it, and the inside top part of your mouth is called the roof.

She opened her mouth to speak.

sorry.

ashamed, embarrassed, or unhappy about something that you have done.

Tell your sister you’re sorry!

begin.

to start doing something.

begin doing something: He began shouting at them.

love.

to like or enjoy something very much.

We went to Vancouver last year and loved it.

car.

a road vehicle for one driver and a few passengers. Someone who drives a car is called a driver.

I’ll take you to the train station in the car.

class.

a group of students who are taught together.

Do you like the other kids in your class?

be.

used for forming the progressive tenses of verbs, that are used for showing actions that are in progress at a particular point in time.

Is everyone listening?

computer.

a machine that stores programs and information in electronic form and can be used for a variety of processes, for example writing, calculating, and communicating on the internet.

All our computers are linked to a main network.

different.

not the same as another person or thing, or not the same as before.

I tried on lots of different hats.

fine.

if something is fine, it is good enough and acceptable to you.

“Is your room all right?” “Yes, it’s fine, thanks.”

fun.

enjoyment, especially from an activity that is not important or serious.

have fun: We haven’t had such fun for years.

cheap.

not expensive.

People should have access to cheap, fresh food.

tea.

a hot brown drink made by pouring boiling water onto the dried leaves of the tea bush. The leaves are called tea leaves and can be bought in small paper bags called tea bags that are put into a cup or teapot.

Do you want some more tea?

give.

to put something in someone’s hand, or to pass something to someone.

give someone something: Could you give me that pen?

hungry.

feeling that you want to eat.

We were cold, tired, and hungry.

when.

used for talking about a particular time or situation.

The biggest surprise for Josie was when she was chosen as team captain.

time.

the quantity that you measure using a clock.

Time seemed to pass more quickly than before.

up.

upright, or moving toward an upright position.

He stood up and pulled a chair out for me to sit on.

child.

a young person from the time they are born until they are about 14 years old.

The center has places for 30 children.

know.

to have learned or found out about something.

If you don’t know the answer, just guess.

dog.

an animal kept as a pet, for guarding buildings, or for hunting. A young dog is called a puppy.

Have you fed the dog?

ball.

a round object used in games and sports.

Try to kick the ball into the back of the net.

toilet.

a structure like a seat over a hole where you get rid of waste from your body.

Can I use your toilet?

door.

a large flat object that you open when you want to enter or leave a building, room, or vehicle.

a little house with a red door

farm.

an area of land used for growing crops or keeping animals.

on a farm: Patrick worked on a neighboring farm.

fast.

able to move quickly.

Simon loves fast cars.

carry.

to hold someone or something using your hands, arms, or body and take them somewhere.

Do you mind carrying this box for me?

warm.

fairly hot in a way that is comfortable and pleasant.

It was warm enough for us to sit outside.

girl.

a female child.

There are 12 boys and 15 girls in my son’s class.

buy.

to get something by paying money for it.

I need to buy some new clothes.

about.

used when you are making an extreme statement that you think is almost completely true or is probably true.

Pam’s about the only person that I can trust.

soup.

a liquid food that is made by cooking meat, fish, vegetables, etc. with water or milk.

chicken/tomato/potato soup

take.

to move something or someone from one place to another.

Don’t forget to take an extra pair of shoes.

flat.

level and parallel to the ground.

The building has a flat roof.

never.

at no time in the past or in the future.

I’ve never been in love before.

do.

used before another verb for forming a question or a negative.

Do you drive?

come.

to move or travel to the place where you are.

come across/along/down/into etc.: A tall woman in black was coming across the lawn.

light.

brightness from the sun or from a light, which allows you to see things.

The room gets a lot of light in the afternoons.

nice.

attractive, enjoyable, or pleasant.

Your hair looks nice.

bread.

a common food made from flour, water, and usually yeast  (=a substance that makes the bread grow larger). Bread is usually sold in a large piece called a loaf or made into smaller pieces called rolls. You usually cut bread into slices to eat it.

bread and butter

use.

to do something using a machine, tool, skill, method, etc. in order to do a job or to achieve a result.

Using a computer is so much quicker.

apple.

.

found.

to start an organization, company, political party, etc..

The newspaper was founded in 1909.

open.

if a store, restaurant, etc. is open, people are working there and the public can use or visit it.

Is the mall open until midnight?

old.

used for talking about the age of someone or something.

how old: She didn’t mention how old her children were.

player.

someone who plays a particular game or sport.

a tennis/baseball player

poor.

having little money and few possessions.

a poor family/area/country

cheese.

a solid food made from milk.

a piece of cheese

really.

very, or very much.

some really useful information

game.

an activity that you do for fun that has rules, and that you can win or lose.

Monopoly is a game for all the family.

station.

a building or place where buses, trains, or other public vehicles stop so that passengers can get on or off.

It was dark when we arrived at the station.

see.

to notice someone or something using your eyes.

She laughed when she saw the expression on his face.

start.

to begin to happen or take place.

The World Championships start in two weeks.

town.

a place where people live and work that is smaller than a city.

a small town

often.

on many occasions, or in many situations.

Often, students with family problems have difficulties at school.

today.

on this day.

I’m working today.

wait.

to stay in one place because you expect or hope that something will happen.

Sheryl said she’d be waiting in the lobby.

jacket.

a short coat that covers the upper part of the body and is made in many styles for different occasions and different kinds of weather.

a tweed/linen/denim jacket

back.

returning to a place or position.

I’m never going back home.

subject.

an idea, problem, situation, etc. that you discuss or write about.

Can we talk about a different subject please?

some.

used for referring to an amount of something or to a number of people or things, without saying how much or how many.

Let me give you some advice.

bottom.

the lowest part of something.

The page had a line missing from the bottom.

beach.

an area of sand or small stones beside the ocean or a lake.

a sandy beach

ready.

prepared for what is going to happen.

We’ll never be ready in time.

book.

a written work that is published, either as printed pages inside a cover or electronically.

a book by Nelson Mandela, entitled Long Walk to Freedom

go.

to move or travel to a place that is away from where you are now.

Where did Sue go?

wake.

to stop sleeping.

I woke at 5 o’clock this morning.

morning.

the part of the day from when the sun rises until noon.

What time did you get up this morning?

goodbye.

used when you are leaving someone or when someone is leaving you, or when you are finishing a telephone call. Bye is a more informal word and is a more common way of saying goodbye to a friend or to someone you know well.

“Goodbye, Mr. Taylor.” “Goodbye, John.”

bad.

not pleasant or enjoyable.

The weather was really bad – it rained all week.

better.

more satisfactory, appropriate, pleasant, effective, or of higher quality, etc..

She’s trying to find a better job.

sister.

a daughter of your parents. A son of your parents is called your brother.

He has two brothers and two sisters.

bag.

a container made of paper, plastic, or cloth, used for carrying or storing things.

Put your dirty clothes in the plastic bag.

find.

to discover something, or to see where it is by searching for it.

The police have found a weapon.

glasses.

an object that you wear in front of your eyes to help you see better. You usually get your glasses from an optometrist.

Where are my glasses?

difficult.

not easy to do, deal with, or understand.

Choosing the winner was a difficult task.

short.

measuring a small height, length, or distance.

She’s short and thin, with light brown hair and blue eyes.

ear.

one of the two parts at the sides of your head that you hear with.

He whispered something in her ear.

street.

a road in a town or city with houses or other buildings along it.

State Street/Fourth Street

juice.

the liquid that comes out of fruit or vegetables when you squeeze them and is often used as a drink.

orange/apple/carrot juice

show.

to prove that something exists or is true.

The study shows an increase in the disease among the elderly.

present.

existing or happening now.

The present situation cannot be allowed to continue.

same.

used for saying that a particular person or thing is the one that you are referring to and not a different one.

Sometimes U.N. troops and their commanders may not even speak the same language.

next.

used for referring to the time, event, action, person, etc. that comes after this one or after another one.

He said he was leaving for Rome the next day.

river.

a large area of water that flows toward the ocean.

the Mississippi River

minute.

a period of 60 seconds. There are 60 minutes in one hour.

I’ll meet you downstairs in ten minutes.

tired.

needing to rest or sleep.

She was too tired to do any more.

half.

used for saying that something happens partly but not completely, or that something is partly in a particular state.

Through the half open door I could hear the sound of Alan’s voice.

many.

a large number of people, things, places, etc..

Did you get many responses to your advertisement?

clever.

good at achieving what you want, especially by using unusual or slightly dishonest methods.

With a clever lawyer, she could easily be acquitted.

village.

a very small old town in the countryside, usually in a country outside the U.S. and Canada.

a Scottish fishing village

thanks.

used for telling someone that you are grateful for something that they have said or done.

“You’re looking well.” “Thanks.”

phone.

a piece of electronic equipment that you use for speaking to someone in a different place.

May I use the phone in your office?

wrong.

not accurate or correct.

We must have gone the wrong way.

enjoy.

to get pleasure from something.

Do you enjoy cooking or do you just see it as a chore?

young.

someone who is young has lived for only a short time.

She’s married with two young children.

cake.

a sweet food made by baking a mixture that usually contains sugar, eggs, flour, and butter or oil.

a chocolate cake

body.

the whole physical structure of a person or animal, including the head, arms, and legs.

My whole body ached.

sugar.

a sweet substance consisting of very small white or brown pieces that is added to food or drinks to make them taste sweet.

Do you like sugar in your coffee?

work.

to have a job, usually one that you are paid to do.

Dominic works part-time.

coat.

a piece of clothing with long sleeves that you wear over your other clothes when you go outside. A short coat is also called a jacket and a long coat is also called an overcoat.

a woman wearing a fur coat

paper.

the thin flat substance that you use for writing on or wrapping things in.

a package wrapped in brown paper

great.

very good, enjoyable, or attractive.

This cake tastes great.

reading.

the process of recognizing written or printed words and understanding their meaning.

My little boy is having difficulty with his reading.

hi.

hello.

Hi, Dad. Just calling to say we’ll be home late tonight.

inside.

in someone’s mind, but not always shown or expressed.

He was silent, but Elizabeth could sense the anger burning inside him.

draw.

to create a picture by making lines with a pen or pencil.

Someone had drawn a map of the island.

last.

used for referring to the week, month, year, etc. that ended most recently.

last week/year/Saturday etc.: How did you boys sleep last night?

talk.

to use words to communicate.

Can their baby talk yet?

worried.

unhappy because you are thinking about your problems or about bad things that could happen.

Everyone was very worried when John didn’t show up.

run.

to move quickly to a place using your legs and feet.

You’ll have to run if you want to catch the school bus.

drive.

to control a vehicle so that it moves somewhere.

Please drive carefully.

table.

a piece of furniture that consists of a flat surface held above the floor, usually by legs.

the kitchen/dining room table

clock.

an object that shows the time. The object like a clock that you wear on your wrist is called a watch. Clocks either have a background called a face with hands that point to the hours and minutes, or they are digital clocks that show the time as a set of numbers. You say a clock is slow when it shows a time that is earlier than the correct time. You say it is fast when it shows a time that is later than the correct time..

The only sound was the clock ticking.

brother.

a boy or man who has the same parents as you.

My brother’s name is Brian.

travel.

to go on a trip or visit a number of places, especially places that are far away from where you live or work.

I wish I didn’t have to travel so much.

dear.

used in front of someone’s name at the beginning of a letter to them.

Dear Diana, I hope you’re feeling better now.

potato.
